text: the Americans shoot the American school
the Algerians lose never mind the
commentator consoles these disappointed
Iraqis this is Steven far over the New
York Times in Baghdad where Iraqis
overcame electricity blackouts and
security scares to watch the United
States soccer team defeat their fellow
Arabs Algeria in the World Cup
government they don't let us footballers
of our chances they took advantage of
one chance and this court Algeria all of
us are Algeria we support any team that
plays against America we support Algeria
seven years after the american invasion
of iraq there was little or no support
for the United States team is this
freedom is this freedom there is no
electricity no water diseases salaries
are low we got rid of the tyrant Saddam
and now we are destroyed and we still
have the same seller most said they
supported argyria for sporting reasons
and our solidarity but years of
murderous sectarian violence here and
yet another 120 degrees summer without
electricity have left many Iraqis angry
and in no mood to back the US Iraq
soccer team isn't part of the world cup
they were they were knocked out in the
qualifying rounds to too much
disappointment here but soccer is a part
of Iraq very much so
in 2007 here in Baghdad the world
workers celebrations when Iraq won the
regional asian cup beating its wealthier
neighbor Saudi Arabia tournaments such
as the mondial as they call it here once
every four years it gives a long
isolated and still very troubled country
a sense that it belongs to a world
community 10 minutes before kickoff in
the US vs algeria game and this poor
district of Sadr City was deserted there
is a giant screen to watch the world cup
but residents say the security forces
shut it down two days ago because they
were afraid bombers would target large
crowds like everywhere else in the world
in this truly global sport Iraqi
children who are or used to playing on
hard dry uneven brown pitches they can
look at the green fields of South Africa
and they can dream that one day in four
years or 80s or 12 years they will play
in a World Cup
